content:
The "Commission on Securing the United States in the 21st Century Act of 2008" establishes a commission with duties outlined in the Act. The Commission established by the "Commission on Securing the United States in the 21st Century Act of 2008" is tasked with conducting a comprehensive review of the global security environment, developing a national security strategy, and creating a detailed plan to achieve the strategy. This includes defining security goals, outlining policy instruments, and identifying steps for implementation. The Commission established by the "Commission on Securing the United States in the 21st Century Act of 2008" is responsible for reviewing budgetary allocations, recommending changes to the national security system, and submitting detailed reports to the President and Congress. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 13 members appointed by various officials, including the Speaker of the House, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of State, and the Director of National Intelligence. The Commission consists of 13 members appointed by various officials, including the Speaker of the House, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of State, and the Director of National Intelligence. Two members each are appointed by the minority leaders of the Senate and the House of Representatives. Prohibited appointments include individuals who are officers or employees of the Federal, State, or local government. Not more than seven members appointed can be of the same political party. Members of the Commission should be prominent US citizens with expertise in various fields. Each member serves for life, vacancies do not affect the Commission's duties, and appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. The Commission shall consist of seven members to form a quorum for hearings. Meetings must begin within 15 days of member appointments and can be called by the chairperson or majority. Members are paid based on the Executive Schedule level IV rate for each day of duty. Travel expenses are provided according to regulations. Members of the Commission are entitled to per diem in lieu of subsistence while away from their homes or regular places of business for Commission services, as per applicable provisions in title 5, United States Code. SEC. 6. STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The chairperson, with consultation from the vice-chairperson, can appoint a staff director and necessary personnel without following standard appointment procedures. The staff director and personnel will be compensated without adhering to standard pay classification rules, with a maximum pay limit set. The Commission can request Federal agencies to detail personnel to assist in their duties without reimbursement. They can also hire experts and consultants at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission has powers to request assistance from Federal agencies and hire experts and consultants at specified rates. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, receive evidence, enter into contracts, and obtain official information from federal agencies to carry out its duties under this Act. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission and its staff must handle information in accordance with laws and regulations. Commission members and staff should receive appropriate security clearances for access to classified information. The General Services Administration will provide administrative support services to the Commission upon request. The Commission may accept gifts, bequests, or devises of services or property to aid its work. Money and proceeds from sales of property received as gifts shall be deposited in the Treasury for disbursement upon the chairperson's order. The Commission may use the United States mails for communication, following the same rules as other government agencies. SEC. 8. REPORTS.

The Commission may submit interim and final reports to the President and Congress, with public disclosure required. 

SEC. 9. TERMINATION.

The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting its final report, with activities allowed until then.

SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for $2,000,000 in fiscal year 2008 is allowed under this Act, with funds remaining available until expended.
